quizInfo.title: What Type of PBMC Are You?
quizInfo.description: Discover which peripheral blood mononuclear cell type matches your personality! This fun quiz connects your traits to different immune cell types.

cellTypes.CD4+:
CD4+ T cell ‚Äì The Coach üó£Ô∏è

You're the motivator, always steering the group toward success. In lab meetings you shine by guiding discussion, and outside the lab, you're the one hyping up your friends. You're a team player who thrives when everyone else thrives too.
cellTypes.CD8+:
CD8+ T cell ‚Äì The Warrior ‚öîÔ∏è

You're direct, bold, and decisive. In meetings you cut straight to the point, and in life you don't shy away from challenges. You bring intensity and focus that keeps everyone on their toes.
cellTypes.Œ≥Œ¥ T:
Œ≥Œ¥ T cell ‚Äì The Wildcard üé≤

Quirky, creative, and a little chaotic ‚Äî you're the one who brings fresh energy and surprises. Whether it's thrifting, vibing, or brainstorming, you keep things unpredictable in the best way.
cellTypes.NK:
NK cell ‚Äì The Lone Wolf üê∫

Independent and instinct-driven, you like to hang back, observe, and strike when the moment calls for it. You don't need the spotlight, but people know you're quietly dependable.
cellTypes.B:
B cell ‚Äì The Archivist üìö

You're detail-oriented and memory-driven. In lab meetings you're the one taking notes, and outside, you're the one with receipts, playlists, and archives of the group's best moments.
cellTypes.Monocyte:
Monocyte ‚Äì The Multitasker üîÑ

Practical, flexible, and hands-on. You don't mind doing the grunt work if it keeps things moving, whether in the lab or in group life. You're the unsung hero who makes sure nothing falls apart.
cellTypes.Dendritic:
Dendritic cell ‚Äì The Storyteller üì°

You're the communicator, the social bridge. You thrive on connecting people and making sure information flows smoothly. In presentations, you're the one who frames the big picture.
cellTypes.Treg:
Regulatory T cell (Treg) ‚Äì The Peacekeeper ‚òÆÔ∏è

Balanced, empathetic, and calming, you keep things from spiraling. You're the vibe stabilizer of your group ‚Äî the one who quietly makes sure everyone feels okay.

questions.question: In a lab meeting, when you have something to say‚Ä¶
options: Raise your hand and guide the discussion constructively.
Interrupt to cut straight to the point.
Blurt out something unexpected that makes people laugh.
Mostly observe quietly, waiting for the right time.
Take detailed notes so nothing gets lost.
Volunteer to follow up later if no one else will.
Frame your point as a story so everyone connects.
Mediate when tensions rise.

questions.question: When others are presenting, how do you usually give feedback?
options: Encouraging and supportive.
Direct and blunt ‚Äî they'll thank you later.
Offbeat or funny, sometimes tangential but memorable.
Short, concise, maybe just a nod.
Remind them of details from last time.
Point out gaps and suggest practical fixes.
Recap their key point for clarity.
Soften harsh critiques with diplomacy.

questions.question: A teammate is clearly struggling but hasn't asked for help. What do you do?
options: Step in with gentle coaching.
Take over the hard parts so the project moves forward.
Suggest an offbeat hack they never thought of.
Keep an eye on them but only step in if asked.
Send them your notes and resources.
Roll up your sleeves and work alongside them.
Call attention so the group can support them.
Quietly check in to reassure them.

questions.question: At an office party, you are‚Ä¶
options: The host, making sure everyone feels welcome.
The challenger, starting competitive games.
The chaotic one in a thrifted outfit making TikToks.
The observer at the edge, sipping your drink.
The photo-documentarian, capturing memories.
The logistics person, keeping food and drinks stocked.
The social butterfly, introducing everyone.
The one calming drama when it flares.

questions.question: In your group, who are you when it comes to the vibe?
options: The motivator, hyping people up.
The one who sets the pace and energy.
The chaotic wild energy.
The calm anchor.
The playlist curator or memory-keeper.
The one making sure snacks/water/logistics are covered.
The MC who makes everyone feel included.
The diffuser who keeps things chill when people clash.

questions.question: What's your ideal weekend activity?
options: Hosting a study group or workshop.
Training hard at the gym or competing.
Thrifting with friends for weird treasures.
Solo hiking or quiet retreat.
Scrapbooking, journaling, or organizing.
Volunteering or helping someone move.
Throwing a dinner party.
Meditation or yoga.

questions.question: How do you act in a group project?
options: Guide everyone and keep the team on track.
Jump in and do the hardest parts directly.
Come up with weird but creative solutions.
Work quietly on your own piece.
Keep the project notes and references organized.
Fill in wherever people are slacking.
Present the group's work to make it shine.
Smooth over group conflicts.

questions.question: Pick a motto that fits you best.
options: Together we win.
Action speaks louder than words.
Think outside the box.
Trust your instincts.
Knowledge is power.
Adapt and overcome.
Communication is key.
Keep calm and carry on.

questions.question: Your favorite kind of movie is‚Ä¶
options: Inspirational sports movie.
Action thriller.
Experimental indie.
Mystery or survival story.
Historical drama.
Disaster movie.
Documentary.
Heartwarming family film.

questions.question: If you were a lab reagent‚Ä¶
options: A versatile buffer that helps everything else work.
A restriction enzyme, cutting straight to the point.
A random mutagen ‚Äî unpredictable results!
A stable preservative, always guarding.
A sequencing library, storing info for later.
A pipette tip, always ready for the next task.
A fluorescent dye, making things visible.
A stabilizer, preventing unwanted reactions.

questions.question: You're graduating with a PhD ‚Äî what's next?
options: Mentor and train the next generation.
Dive into high-stakes industry work.
Take a nontraditional path (startup, art, politics‚Ä¶).
Step back, rest, and protect your energy.
Publish and archive your work for others.
Do hands-on applied work in the field.
Become a science communicator or policy advocate.
Support mental health and balance in academia.
